title: gangs behind beckham raid jewellery heist
story: Chilling CCTV from a burglary just  miles from the Beckham’s country retreat earlier this year shows thieves wearing identical tracksuits, masks and gloves stalking the mansion’s grounds.Cops are still probing the raid at the home of biotech tycoon Sir Christopher Evans - worth £million - where the raiders fled with the loot stashed in log baskets in July.The same gang of masked crooks are also feared to be behind at break in at the home of widow of “fth Beatle” Sir George Martin in March.Judy Martin, , who also lives just  miles from the Beckhams Oxfordshire bolthole, was watching TV late at night when raiders smashed their way through her conservatory in March this year.She heard the gang as she and called the cops. The crooks escaped empty handed.Victims are convinced that it is the same group of robbers terrorising the picturesque villages.The gang always wear similar gear and use ladders to jump the walls of the flash Cotswold mansions.David,  and Victoria,  were said to be shocked that their country home was targeted on Saturday, with the three men using ladders to peer into the £ million home in Great Tew, Oxfordshire.The home is next to trendy Soho Farmhouse, which hosted Meghan’s Markle’s hen do, while the Duke and Duchess of Sussex also have a new home nearby.Sir Christopher, , was burgled back in July where they made off with their loot stashed in log baskets.Raiders struck at Glebe House in Bibury on July  hey then carried their haul across the grounds and fled in a dark Audi towards Cirencester.A friend of Sir Christopher told The Sun last night he felt confident the crooks were part of the same gang that targeted his property.He said: “I spoke with him Monday morning - he wishes the Beckhams all the best and hopes Oxfordshire Police catches them.“From the pictures we’ve seen I would say it was the same people that targeted them.They looked very, very similar – the way they moved – even the way they were dressed.“It’s only  minutes or so from here, the knowledge we have got from the police, the way they do things – it seems to fit.“From what I have seen, the way they are, it looks like the same crew.Back in July, Sir Christopher’s we Anne,  said: “They have wiped out my entire jewellery collection. It’s serious money. There were hundreds of items and a lot of them were unbelievably special.“Me and my son were in the house at the time. We were so lucky we didn’t come across them, these guys were prepared. I feel so devastated and violated.”Lady Martin declined to comment yesterday.A local source said: “All the local police forces are working together to try and tackle crime like this.“With all the well-known people in the area it’s known they will be targeted.”Last month four men were arrested in connection with the raid on Sir Christopher Evan’s mansion were arrested but realised without charge.Thames Valley Police confirmed the Beckhams had been targeted.A TVP spokesman said: “Thames Valley Police were called to Great Tew, Enstone, Chipping Norton, Oxfordshire on Saturdayat pm.“There were reports of a burglary in progress. On attendance, no one was found, there wasn’t any damage caused and there was also no evidence of entry being made to the building. Nothing was taken.”The spokesman added: “The investigation has been filed pending any further information coming to light, anyone with information is asked to call .No arrests have been made at this time.“As always with any report that comes in to Thames Valley Police, we would keep an open mind as to whether this is linked to any other incident, but at this time it is not being linked to anything .”LADDER GANG STRIKE ONEVictim: Lady Judy MartinWhere: Coleshill, OxonWhen: March How: Scaling a wall and smashing the conservatoryTook: Nothing after Lady Martin called the police.LADDER GANG STRIKE TWOVictim: Sir Christopher Evans and we Lady Anne.Where: Bibury, Gloucs When: July How: Scaling a wall and smashing the conservatoryTook: £ million in jewellery including: Diamond solitaire ring, Cartier Platinum and white gold diamond line bracelet with  step cut diamonds  gold, diamond and sapphire tiara, late th century.LADDER GANG STRIKE THREEVictims: David and Victoria BeckhamWhere: Great Tew, OxfordshireWhen: October  How: Scaling a wall and using a ladder to look into the houseTook: Nothing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit done general election
story: The PM was forced to endure a painful grilling from her own MPs in the Commons, who accuse her of giving too much ground to Brussels in Brexit negotiations.Updating MPs on last week’s EU summit, Mrs May dubbed the continuing row with Brussels over how to avoid a hard border in Ireland as “the one real sticking point left, but a considerable one”.Tackling fury over her suggestion last week for a possible extension to the  month transition period, she insisted the move would be “undersirable” and hopefully unnecessary.She also pledged to rip up the EU’s backstop plan to keep the Irish border open and replace with her own UK-wide option that would not ide up the UK - a movce that will anger the EU.And both “insurance” options would end “well before the end of this Parliament”, plus the UK would also have a well-defined escape root from both, she insisted.Appealing for more patience, Mrs May told MPs: “Serving our national interest will demand that we hold our nerve through these last stages of the negotiations, the hardest part of all”.But the assurances failed to win over Brexiteer backbenchers, who insisted they all be enshrined in binding legal commitments in the Brexit deal.Former Cabinet minister John Whittingdale fumed at the PM: “It is now over two years since the referendum, and we have agreed that we will not gain control of our laws, borders and money for over four years.“Does she understand that for many, that is already too long Jacob Rees-Mogg, who leads the Eurosceptic European Research Group added: “Does the Prime Minister know where she is going ”Remainers also attacked her, with former minister Anns Soubry saying small businesses “are in state of despair” because they still don’t know what the UK’s future relationship with the EU will be.Mrs May also couldn’t offer angry Scottish Tory MPs the promise that she would not trade away Britain’s newly-won back fishing rights in any future trade deal.In another bid to reassure fretful Cabinet ministers today, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab will give an update to Cabinet on no deal preparations and insist the emergency planning is on track.THE PM must never give in on an endless transition period.It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve.Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility. story: They say they had to endure over-flowing bins and dumped garbage bags.During the hot summer a skip was parked outside the flat which was often full of refuse, including human waste.The flats toilet drain was frequently blocked causing a foul pong.Neighbours claim the GP Balvinder Mehat the landlord knew the flat was over crowded and ignored their repeated pleas to tackle the problem.But the medic - who runs a nearby surgery and was arrested by cops last year over claims he had circumcised a baby without its mums permission - said last night he had only rented the property out to a couple.They told him they had had visitors staying temporarily.Now the Nottingham city council has taken action and confirmed that when they checked there were  people including young kids living in the flat over a boarded up shop in the Bakersfield area of the city.Desperate residents begged had council to intervene saying overcrowding in the flat had made their lives a misery.One angry neighbour,who asked not to be named for fear of reprisals said: The Romanians moved in about a year ago. story: The Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt said he was waiting for a credible explanation of the death and would act accordinglyour crucial Gulf ally was found to have breached our “values”.And Mr Hunt said he was studying “any implications that arise” from “appalling brutality”, branding the current explanations of his death “not credible.”Prime Minister Theresa May condemned the killing “in the strongest possible terms” and added “we must get to the truth of what happened”.Mr Hunt acknowledged that the UK had close security and business links with Saudi Arabia but “ the appalling stories we are reading turn out to be true” the UK “will act accordingly”.He told MPs: “We have an important strategic partnership with Saudi Arabia involving defence and security co-operation which has saved lives on the streets of Britain.We also have a trading partnership that supports thousands of jobs.“So whilst we will be thoughtful and considered in our response.I have also been lear thatthe appalling stories we are reading turn out to be true, they are fundamentally incompatible with our values and we will act accordingly.Mr Hunt said: “The actions Britain and our allies take will depend on two things: firstly the credibility of the final explanation given by Saudi Arabia, and secondly on our confidence that such an appalling episode cannot - and will not - be repeated.”Asked directly about arms sales, Mr Hunt said: “We keep the situation constantly under review, including any implications that arise from the Khashoggi investigation.”The admission came as Labour said the Government were being “played for fools” by Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry said the Prime Minister looks “foolish” having hosted the Crown Prince on a state visit earlier this year. title: brexiteers accused of going over theresa mays head with direct pitch to michel barnier
story: Former Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith and ex Cabinet minister Owen Paterson were blasted for trashing the PM’s customs plan at a meeting with the Frenchman in Brussels.The pair presented Mr Barnier with a report, authored by the hardline ERG group, which argues in favour of a “Max Fac” arrangement instead.It is understood that during the meeting, which was also attended by Brexit-backing peer Lord Trimble, the trio described the Chequers customs plan as “unworkable”.And they said it was only eurocrats’ intransigence standing in the way of “near frictionless trade” between the UK and EU after Brexit.Mr Duncan Smith, who was ousted as Tory leader following a no confidence vote, was forced to deny plotting a similar fate for Mrs May.Pressed on whether he was undermining the PM, he replied “no, absolutely not” and insisted she had his “full support, that’s it, full stop”.He added: “It was nothing to do with undermining the Prime Minister. We weren’t there to negotiate, we were just there to present.“This is all within a par of what the Government says they want to achieve, which is ultimately leave on the best terms and the best arrangements.”Mr Paterson added that eurosceptic were “fully behind” the PM despite publicly opposing her Brexit plan.He said: “We’ve got Article  passed, we’ve got the Withdrawal Act passed and now what we want to see is this end arrangement.”But Tory MP Antoinette Sandbach fumed: “We’re fed up of seeing the ERG bullying and undermining the PM because of their so called ‘vision’ of Brexit.“They undermine the UK’s negotiating position and constantly block solutions.”EU leaders have repeatedly rejected a technological solution to the Irish border, known as “Max Fac”, claiming it is unworkable.One senior official told The Sun that such technology might not be workable until .But eurosceptics are reviving the argument, previously floated then killed by Downing Street in favour of Chequers, as they seek a Canada-style trade deal.Mr Duncan Smith said: “We think it solves the backstop but also paves the way for a trade agreement.”Solving the Irish border issue is the last remaining roadblock to the two sides sealing a withdrawal agreement.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: south western railway strikes five day walkouts london uk today
story: South Western Railway passengers heading into the capital from Surrey, Hampshire, Berkshire, Dorset, Somerset and Devon will be met with reduced services from this morning.The strikes are expected to be the longest in the two year dispute over the future of the role of guards on trains and come as the half-term break begins this week.About two thirds of normal weekday services are expected to run on SWR this week.There will be no South Western Railway service from Exeter to Yeovil and passengers have been advised there will be rail placement buses available.Meanwhile, there will be no SWR service – or replacement bus service - from Bristol towards London from today.Services will be disrupted following the RMT’s decision to strike between Tuesday and Saturday following the ongoing dispute regarding the role of guards on trains.Other routes operating on a reduced service into London Waterloo include trains from Weymouth, Southampton, Portsmouth, Basingstoke, Woking, Epsom and Reading.SWR urged the RMT to call off the strikes and has hit out at the union for “cynically targeting hard-working commuters, families and sports fans”.A SWR spokesman said: “The RMT is cynically targeting hard-working commuters, families trying to enjoy the half-term holidays and sports fans with its latest strike dates.Southampton - London WaterlooPortsmouth - London WaterlooAlton - London WaterlooDorking - London WaterlooYeovil - London WaterlooReading - London WaterlooBristol - London WaterlooExeter - London Waterloo “We have guaranteed a guard to be rostered on every single service, and our growth plans mean more guards, not fewer. It is time for the union to stop spreading myths and causing misery to our customers and colleagues, and commit to resolving this dispute.“If the union decides to continue with its unnecessary action, we will do everything we can to keep our customers moving and reduce disruption.”But the RMT hit back and Mick Cash, RMT General Secretary, accused SWR of “stalling the talks process”.He said: “South Western Railway has stalled the talks process and has failed to provide any sort of offer that comes close to resolving this dispute which matches the widespread best practice in the industry, underpinned by the guard guarantee.With shocking new figures from the British Transport Police showing a surge in violence on our railways it is frankly appalling that South Western Railway are looking for a green light to throw the guard off their trains as and when they see fit in the name of profit.It comes as rail passengers in Scotland are facing major disruptions this morning after engineering works overran near Glasgow Queen Street.No trains are running out of the high-level station, which is affecting services to Edinburgh and Aberdeen.Network Rail said a piece of machinery broke down shortly before am on Tuesday and they are working to remove it.ScotRail said it was working to secure replacement buses and stressed that low-level services to Edinburgh were not affected.A Network Rail spokesman said: Overnight, Network Rail engineers were carrying out work to the track and overhead line equipment at Cowlais.Shortly before ., a piece of machinery broke down. Network Rail workers are currently working to remove the failed equipment.Due to the nature of the incident, no trains are currently able to run from the high-level s at Glasgow Queen Street railway station.Passengers are urged to check before they travel via National Rail Enquiries or with their train operator.Wed like to apologise for any disruption this incident is causing and thank passengers for their patience.

title: greek odysseus trading vessel 2400 years found intact black sea
story: The ancient Greek trading ship was found whole, bow to stern, with even its mast, rudders and rowing benches almost perfectly preserved.The ship looks almost identical to a vessel shown on a vase in the British Museum depicting Greek hero Odysseus voyage home from the Trojan war.Scientists at the Black Sea Maritime Archaeology Project determined the  foot vessel was consigned to Davy Jones’ Locker more than , years ago.It was found in what has been described as a “shipwreck graveyard” where over  other sunken ships have been discovered.The ship was found in  by a remote controlled submarine piloted by Brit scientists but has just been confirmed as the “oldest intact shipwreck”.It has the design of an Ancient Greek trading vessel design previously only seen on the side of ancient Greek pottery such as the “Siren Vase” in the British Museum.The ship is over . miles deep on the bed of the Black Sea where the water is oxygen free, around  miles off the coast of Bulgaria.This “anoxic” water can preserve organic material for millennia and a small piece of the vessel has been carbon dated to BC.It revealed the accuracy of the painter of the Siren Vase who painted an almost identical vessel onto the pottery.Jon Adams, professor of archaeology at the University of Southampton and chief scientist of the team that found the wreck, told The Times: “Nobody has ever known how accurate the representation on the Siren Vase was and whether the artist was making it up or drawing what he saw.“Now we see archaeological evidence showing a ship very close in detail, even down to the shape of the rudder blade.“The artist must have been familiar with ships.”Prior to this discovery ancient ships had only been found in fragments with the oldest more than , years old.The team from the Black Sea Maritime Archaeological Project said the find also revealed how far from the shore ancient Greek traders could travel.Archaeologist believes it probably held - men at the time whose remains may be hidden in the surrounding sediment or eaten by bacteria.He said he plans to leave the ship on the seabed because raising it would be hugely expensive and require taking some of the joints apart.The ship, which was powered by both sails and oars was mainly used for trade but could have occasionally played a role in battle, raiding coastal cities.The find is one of  wrecks found in the area.Previous finds were discovered dating back as far as , years, including galleys from the Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman empires.The design on the ancient property depicts a scene from Homer’s Odyssey, one of the oldest and most famous stories in history.It details the tale of Odysseus and his ten year journey back from fighting in the Trojan War.On the epic voyage he encounters numerous mythological figures including a Cyclops, gods and goddesses and even a visit to the underworld.But one of the most famous scenes, as depicted on the vase, involves the eponymous hero ordering his crew to lash him to lash him to the mast and block his ears to resist the “Siren’s call”Sirens were dangerous creatures who would lure sailors to shipwreck on the rock coasts with their enchanting songs.They were said to be a combination of women and birds.

story: The Duke of Sussex, , was told by his staff to wrap up his chat with Gwen Cherne, , at Sydney Harbour Bridge during his first royal tour with we Meghan.However, the widow revealed that Harry said he was “in the middle of a conversation” and continued his emotional talk with grieving Gwen on Friday, reports People.She said: “He stopped and said, Im in a middle of a conversation, and Im not going to leave this.We were talking about my story and mental health and how dficult it is still, in our society, to talk about grief and loss and suicide.”The pair even shared a hug together after their heartfelt chat.Gwen, who was part of a group climbing the famous bridge in Sydney with Harry, lost her husband Peter J. Café after he tragically took his own le.Peter was an Australian special forces officer who served in Cambodia, Afghanistan and Iraq.She is now an ambassador for the Invictus and War Widows Guild following her beloved husband’s death.Created by Harry, the Invictus Games are an international Paralympic-style sporting event for wounded, sick or injured members of the armed forces, as well as veterans.Gwen said she and Harry also discussed how important the event was at “shedding light” on issues such as mental health and “allowing people to start to have these conversations that are great to have.The prince also climbed the bridge with Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison and a group of former veterans turned elite athletes.Harry and Meghan’s royal tour coincides with the fourth Invictus Games which are taking place in Australia’s largest city.The Duke has expressed his personal joy over his wes pregnancy in a moving speech at the sporting events opening ceremony at the Sydney Opera House on Saturday.Prince Harry, who was attending the ceremony with Meghan, said: First of all, thank you for the welcome you have given Meghan and I over the last few days.I have been so proud to be able to introduce my we to you and we have been so happy to be able to celebrate the personal joy of our newest addition with you all.

title: asda manuka honey facebook
story: A photo that was shared on Facebook shows the bright green security tags on the Rowse Manuka honey, which is selling for a dear £..Shoppers were quick to mock the supermarket over their security measures and the price it was charging.Beth Peterson took the photo and shared it while she was shopping in Asda last night in South Shields, County Durham.She added the caption: “I’ve never laughed so hard in my le!!“I know it’s stupid for laughing, but found it funny that there is a security tag on hunny.”Beth told The Sun Online she was surprised to see the jars of Manuka honey on the shelf with the security tags on it.She said: “I was Hysterical laughing, I couldn’t believe that I had just saw a honey jar with a security tag on it “What’s going to be next  Cheese ”She said she was shocked at the price.She said: “I couldn’t believe the price either, I nearly fell through the floor!”Beth, of South Shields, shared the photo to cheer people up.She said: “I just took the pic as it was funny and I thought it could brighten up someone’s day.”Many were quick to comment on the price of the honey.One person commented : “I’m always flabbergasted that people will pay THAT much for honey.”Another added: Its the size of the security tag thats the funniest.Manuka honey is exported from New Zealand and is said to contain antibacterial properties, which contribute to its high price.It is commonly sold as an alternative medicine, despite no conclusive evidence that it has medicinal value.However, that still hasn’t won some over.One said: “health benefits or not.. I wouldn’t be seen spending £ on a jar of bee sick.”An Asda spokeswoman said Manuka honey will always have a security tag because of its retail price.

title: granddad sepsis nail biting
story: Ricky Kennedy from Dumbarton, Scotland, contracted the infection after nibbling down on his thumbnail in January this year.Within hours, the infection spread from his thumb to his arms and chest, resulting in him being hospitalised a couple of days later.The -year-old was only given a  per cent chance of surviving the ordeal, and had to spend months in a hospital bed.The deadly sepsis infection has left him with an eroded collarbone, asthma and septic arthritis.Speaking to the Daily Record, he said: “I’m lucky to be alive. I may never be as healthy or strong as I was but I’m still here with my family and that is very precious to me.”The grandad, who also suffers from type  diabetes, fell ill in January , with the blood poisoning taking hold of his body within hours.Ricky claims that he had bitten his thumbnail down too far, and noticed a tiny blister forming on his thumb.Thinking nothing of it, he initially ignored it but a few hours later, the infection has spread through his blood stream.He added: “All I can remember is asking a nurseI was going to die. It was a terrible time.”Sepsis is the primary cause of death from infection around the world, claiming around , lives in the UK each year – that’s more than more deaths than bowel, breast and prostate cancer combined.The condition is always triggered by an infection.Most often the culprit is an infection we all recognise - pneumonia, urinary infections , skin infections, including cellulitis, and infections in the stomach, for example appendicitis.Typically, when a person suffers a minor cut, the area surrounding the wound will become red, swollen and warm to touch.This is evidence the bodys immune system has kicked into action, releasing white blood cells to the site of the injury to kill off the bacteria causing the infection.The white blood cells and platelets form blood clots in the tissues around the cut.Blood vessels swell to allow more blood to flow, and they become leaky, allowing infection-fighting cells to get out of the blood and into the tissues where they are needed.This causes inflammation, which appears to us as the red, warm swelling.When sepsis happens, this system goes into overdrive.The inflammation that is typically seen just around the minor cut, spreads through the body, affecting healthy tissue and organs.The immune system - the bodys defence mechanism - overreacts and the result is it attacks the body.It can lead to organ failure and septic shock, which can prove fatal.

title: meghan markle holds baby bump prince harry fiji banquet

but the royal couple appeared to laugh it off.The Duchess was presented with a bouquet of flowers by a girl from the chiefly island of Bau, before Harry made his way to a dais on the runway.Bau is the home of Ratu Apensia Cakobau, who ceded Fiji to Britain in .Harry and Meghan observed a royal salute, and the Duke was then invited to inspect the guard of honour.The royal couple then left for their next engagement - a meeting with Fijis President, Jioji Konrote - title: 1917 russian revolution lenin stalin colourised images
story: Striking pictures show Vladimir Lenin disguised as factory worker KP Ivanov at Razliz station in August  as well as Lenin with Joseph Stalin in .Other stunning colour shots show the last Tsar of Russia, Nicholas II with his family and visiting the army in , the Tsar family executor Jakob Jurovsky and the February revolution taking place in .The original black and white photographs were painstakingly colourised by artist Viacheslav Peregudov, , from Irkutsk, Russia.He said: “The crowds were intoxicated by freedom soldiers mixed with civilians.”“The first was the February revolution, which screamed in the squares about equality and brotherhood, followed by the Bolshevik revolution, the civil war.“And youre looking for the point where the giant Empire began its descent to the edge of the abyss.”He continued: “One of the greatest dreams of any person in the world is a time machine. And the greatest regret of any person is that it is impossible to produce this machine in our world.“Not in our time at least but who knows maybe in  years. For now we can do it just in our imagination.“I would say my time machine works on a fuel of imagination and the real colour of the past which is a channel of reality that has been ignored for many years due to black and white images.”The Russian Revolution was a pair of revolutions in Russia in  which dismantled the Tsarist autocracy and led to the rise of the Soviet Union.The Russian Empire collapsed with the abdication of Emperor Nicholas II and the old regime was replaced by a provisional government during the first revolution of February .In the October Revolution, the Bolsheviks led an armed insurrection by workers and soldiers in Petrograd that successfully overthrew the Provisional Government, transferring all its authority to the soviets with the capital being relocated to Moscow shortly thereafter.Soon after, civil war erupted among the Reds , the Whites , the independence movements and the non-Bolshevik socialists.It continued for several years, during which the Bolsheviks defeated both the Whites and all rival socialists and thereafter reconstituted themselves as the Communist Party.In this way, the Revolution paved the way for the creation of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republicsin .Viacheslav began to colourise old photographs around five years ago and was quickly drawn to images of Russia in the early th Century.He added: “When I started my project, it was just a few historical photos.“I didn’t do it for money but just my private pleasure and today it is a collection of more than  colourised photos that were shot in the period from  to .“Sometimes I do colourisation for other photographs but I alwaysto Russia in the early s.”

title: theresa may faces down cabinet critics tory backbench not enough support
story: Backbenchers have mounted a bid to topple the PM by putting in letters calling for a vote of confidence in her leadership.But the Tory shop steward today shot down rumours that the revolt has attracted enough support to unseat Mrs May - meaning she is still safe for now.Graham Brady, chair of the  Committee of backbenchers, must call a vote of confidencehe gets  letters demanding one.After Westminster insiders claimed the threshold had already been reached, Sir Graham told friends the rumours were wrong.He is the only person who knows how many letters have been submitted at any given time.During this mornings Cabinet meeting, Mrs May told ministers she is planning to produce weekly reports on the Brexit talks from now on.The PM will also brief them regularly on how the Government is preparing for a possible No Deal scenario.The briefings are meant to be a show of strength - proving to Brussels that the UK is ready for all possible outcomes.Mrs Mays spokesman said: As we move towards exit day it makes good sense that all ministers are informed about the work taking place for both scenarios.The PM told the Cabinet her priority is preparing for a withdrawal agreement, but stressed Britain will be prepared evenwe leave the EU without a deal.She said Brussels bosses will call an emergency Brexit summit as soon as enough progress has been made to secure a deal.Amber Rudd today dismissed the idea that Mrs May could be unseated by furious Brexiteers.She told the BBC: I do think that shes safe - controversial I know.The fact is, whoever was leading the Conservative party now would have the same problem with the numbers. The numbers are that the MPs are ided on how to leave the European Union.Mrs May received a boost from Brussels today as it was reported the EU is prepared to agree with her demands on the Irish backstop.The PM wants to avoid striking a Brexit deal which would carve off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.Her backstop proposal would see the whole of the UK stay in the EUs customs unionthat was the only way to avoid a hard border in Ireland.Brussels chiefs have previously resisted that suggestion - claiming it would be too dficult to sort out the details in time for Brexit.But today RTE reported that the EU has accepted Mrs Mays plans could be workable as long as both sides sign a separate treaty to enshrine it into law.The compromise brings Britain and the EU a step closer to signing a deal which would ensure a smooth Brexit next year.

title: chinese loner buys puppy discovers rat
story: The man allegedly purchased his new four legged friend from a dog dealer near his home.But after he got the pup back to his flat he noticed that it was behaving weird and didnt walk like a dog, according to Chinese media outlet Shanghaiist.According to reports in the country the man, who had allegedly bought the pet to keep himself company, eventually took to Chinese social media site Weibo to try and identy the new furry addition to his household.Unbelievably users in China eventually identied the dog as a bamboo rat often found in Southern China, Burma and Vietnam, it has been claimed.These rats feed on bamboo shoots and roots, and are allegedly considered delicacies in some Chinese cities.Following his discovery the man has since claimed that he has given his pet away because was unsure of how to properly care for a bamboo rat.The Sun Online has not been able to independently very the claims.This isnt the first time a prospective Chinese pet owner has allegedly had the wool pulled over their eyes when buying an animal.In May, it was reported that another Chinese pet owner had mistaken a  black bear that she found by the road to be a dog, reports The Star.The woman from the south-western province of Yunnan had reportedly raised the Tibetan mastf for two years, before she learnt it was an Asiatic black bear.She later took it to a wildle rescue centre in Yunnan.And in June, a man from north-east Liaoning province claimed he bought a Pomeranian at a local market, only to discover that it was actually a raccoon.

title: hair stylist flips mini cooper roundabout waving
story: Kimberley Howard, , was beeping her horn at a roundabout when she ploughed into a third vehicle being used for a driving lesson in February this year.Her Mini overturned in the crash and ended up on its side leaving Howard with serious injuries.She had to be cut free from the wreckage and suffered lost teeth, bleeding legs and a cut hand and was treated at Wythenshawe Hospital in Manchester.The driver of the L-plated Hyundai car escaped uninjured in the crash on a suburban street in Sale.Police investigated whether Howard from Timperley was on her mobile phone at the time of the impact on February  this year but found no evidence a call was being made.Tests revealed she had cut her hand on the phone when the screen smashed at the point of impact.At Manchester Magistrates Court, Howard who runs a mobile hairdressing service, admitted careless driving but escaped with six penalty points on her licence.She was also fined £ and ordered to pay £ in costs and surcharges.Howard said: I had left my friends house down the road that morning. I came round the roundabout and she was going a dferent way. I beeped and waved at her but I went round the roundabout and then the crash happened. I don’t really remember how it happened.”Prosecuting Tim McArdle said: “It was shortly after lunch time at around .pm. An eye witness was in her vehicle and saw a car beeping in front of her.“She believed it was to attract the attention of another driver. She was beeping at a friend as they travelled around the roundabout.“As she exited the roundabout the car swerved slightly left and hit the passenger side of another car which caused Miss Howard’s car to flip on to its side.“Miss Howard was trapped in the car, her hand was badly cut which could have been from her phone screen as that was smashed.“The police attended and described how after investigating a number of collisions suspected she was distracted by something in the car - it could have been her phone.“Although after checking there was no evidence of a call in progress at the time of the crash, it is unknownit could have been used for something .“She must have been travelling at some speed for the result to be what it was. There were no injuries to others. It was on a Tuesday afternoon in a residential area.”Sentencing chairman of the magistrates Caroline Green told Howard: “I understand you do mobile work so it is very, very important to have your driving licence.“But we need every road user to be conscious and you need to be very, very careful. If you get any more points you will be disqualied.“Something happened on that afternoon and it was a rather nasty accident, and it was fortunate that not more people were hurt.“Given the trauma you have been through medically to get over this incident, you need to be careful - not only for the next three years but for the rest of your driving career.”

title: queen welcomes dutch royals london military display visit forty years
story: The Queen and Mrs May were at the event to formally welcome King Willem-Alexander and Queen Máxima of the Netherlands on their two day trip to London, the first State Visit in almost  years.The Queen wore a deep purple coat and matching hat with black gloves for the occasion and smiled warmly as she greeted the royals on the steps at the Royal Pavilion at Horse Guards Parade.However the Prime Minister appeared to have a slightly more awkward greeting with the Queen as she bowed into an uncomfortable curtsy before joining other officials at the ceremony.The awkward manoeuvre came just two months after she sunk to an incredibly low lunge as she greeted Prince William at a World War One service in Amiens, France.King Willem-Alexander kissed the Queen warmly on both cheeks and clasped her hands with his - a gesture that was repeated by his we Queen Máxima, who wore a blush coat and dress for the occasion.On Horse Guards Parade, the king - making his first official trip to the UK - was also greeted by Britains political leaders including Prime Minister Theresa May, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt and the Home Secretary Sajid Javid.The guard of honour was formed by the st Battalion, Coldstream Guards, in their scarlet tunics and bearskins, with the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment in their shining breast plates and plumed helmets and the Band of the Household Cavalry nearby.The royals then took a state carriage procession along the Mall in London to lunch at Buckingham Palace.The Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwall will then escort Willem-Alexander and Maxima from the Dutch embassy to Whitehall.This afternoon, the Dutch royals will visit the grave of William III and Mary II of England, the Anglo-Dutch couple who ruled Britain at the end of the th Century.They will also lay a wreath at the Grave of the Unknown Soldier in Westminster Abbey.King Willem-Alexander will then deliver an address to parliament before afternoon tea with Prince Charles at his official Clarence House residence.The Dutch monarch has previously spoken of his, and the Dutch governments, regret about Britain withdrawing from the EU.In a press briefing with journalists earlier this month the foreign head of state said he would have liked the British people to have voted to remain in EU but they respected their choice.Later this evening, the Dutch royals will enjoy a banquet as the Queen plans to host a state dinner for her guests at Buckingham Palace.It is not clearshe will be joined by Prince Philip, who retired from royal duties last year.It is the third time the queen has hosted the Dutch royal family for a state visit, with the most recent visit in .The last state visit from the Netherlands was by Queen Beatrix and Prince Claus in November , while Queen Elizabeth and her husband Philip paid a state visit to Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands in March .The State Visit by the Dutch royals will conclude on Wednesday.

title: tory mps pile pressure speaker
story: NewsTory MPs pile pressure on Speaker John Bercow by quitting Commons inclusion committeeMims Davis said staying on the committee “did not sit right” following the Cox ReportShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe committee is chaired by John Bercow "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory MPs are quitting a committee chaired by Commons Speaker John Bercow, following a report on bullying and harassment in Parliament. Dame Laura Cox lted the lid on a toxic environment in Westminster, which included staff having their bottoms and breasts touched in an atmosphere fuelled by ready access to alcohol. Her report found that a culture of deference, subservience, acquiescence and silence had allowed the mistreatment of staff in the House of Commons to thrive. And it heaped pressure on Commons Speaker John Bercow, who has himself been the subject of bullying allegations, which he denies. Today, a string of Tory MPs resigned from the Commons Representation and Inclusion Committee, which is chaired by Speaker Bercow. Mims Davis said staying on the committee “did not sit right” following the Cox Report.  Will Quince and Anne Milton have also reportedly resigned from the committee. The committee is intended to make Parliament more inclusive. The ruling House of Commons Commission meets on Wednesday to discuss the Cox Report, with independent member Jane McCall chairing the  rather than Mr Bercow.

title: brave man confronts driver who
story: NewsBrave man confronts driver who was weaving across road and confiscates his keys until police arriveSkender Safqi, who has been banned from driving, was spotted driving in his black Mercedes along Ashley Road, BournemouthShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video dashcam-footage-shows-motorist-driving-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave man has been hailed by police after confronting a driver who was weaving dangerously across a road. Skender Safqi, who has been banned from driving, was spotted in his black Mercedes on Ashley Road, Bournemouth at around pm on Saturday, April . The car was seen swerving all over the road and crossing into the oncoming carriageway, causing other vehicles to dart out of the way. His driving was captured on the dashcam of a motorist following behind, and caught him mounting the pavement and only narrowly missing pedestrians. A brave motorist following, jumped out of his car at a set of traffic lights, and confronted the driver, taking his keys until police arrived. Two special constables found Safqi, , sitting in the driver’s seat of the Mercedes.  He appeared dazed and confused and was unsteady on his feet, the force said. One of the officers carried out a roadside drug wipe that indicated a positive result for cannabis and Safqi was arrested and taken to Bournemouth Police Station. When in custody he refused to provide a urine sample for analysis. Safqi, of Cromwell Road in Bournemouth, appeared at Bournemouth Crown Court on Friday, October  to be sentenced after admitting offences of dangerous driving and failing to provide a specimen for analysis. He was sentenced to four months in prison, suspended for  months, and ordered to carry out  hours of unpaid work in the community. Safqi was also ordered to pay pound costs and fined pound and disqualied from driving for  months. He must then take an extended test in order to get back his licence. Detective Constable Corina Palmer, of Dorset Police’s Volume Crime Team, said: “Skender Safqi’s driving on April ,  was extremely dangerous and it was only through luck that no members of the public were seriously hurt. “I would like to thank the members of the public who assisted in ensuring his vehicle was stopped, particularly the witness who also captured the incident on dashcam. “This case also shows the value of our special constables, who are a vital part of the No Excuse team and were on scene quickly to carry out the roadsides test and arrest the offender.”  Special Constable Rob Scott, part of Dorset Police’s No Excuse team, said: “Following the incident and investigation we are pleased with the result that a dangerous driver has been taken off the road. “Thank you to the member of the public who called the police and intervened. “Thankfully no one was injured and the driver has been brought to justice.

title: devastated mums miscarriage shower due
story: NewsMum blames miscarriage on Tory benefit cuts after stress killed her babyWARNING - DISTRESSING CONTENT: Victoria Bagnall, , from Glasgow, was on benefits after giving up work to care for her husband and sonShareCommentsByAmanda KeenanChris kitching:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsVictoria Bagnall with her husband Gerald Loftus and their two-year-old son Patrick. "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA grieving mum claims she suffered a devastating miscarriage at home due to stress caused by Tory welfare cuts and her financial struggle. Victoria Bagnall has been living off benefits and supporting her family after giving up work to care for her ailing husband and their two-year-old son. She claims she begged DWP bosses not to halt her Jobseekeers Allowance payments pound every two weeks - but her pleas were ignored. Within hours, Victoria says, she lost her baby as she had a shower at home, the Daily Record reports. The -year-old, from Glasgow, said: “My doctor told me that my miscarriage could have been brought on by stress.  “I was sick with worry. I have worked all my days and had no idea how we were going to be able to survive with no money. “I was having a shower and suddenly I started bleeding heavily. “The next thing I knew, the foetus came out and I grabbed it. It was tiny and just starting to form. “I could see my baby’s eyes, limbs and even its tiny heart. “I didn’t know what to do. I just cried and held our child in my hands until the paramedics arrived.” Victoria was  weeks pregnant when she was sent a letter from the Department for Work and Pensions on October  telling her they were stopping her Jobseekeers Allowance with immediate effect. She was forced to give up her job as a supervisor at soft play centre Whale of a Time after her partner Gerald Loftus, , tore the cruciate ligament in his knee, leaving him unable to look after their toddler Patrick.  Victoria said: “I’ve worked since the day I left school and I had to give up my job to help care for my partner and son. “This is the first time I’ve claimed benefits in my le and it’s not a position I ever thought I’d be in. “Gerald suffered a stroke  years ago and he also struggles with depression. “We always managed to cope until last month when he injured his knee, leaving him in agony and unable to run around after our son. “Patrick was suffering and Gerald was getting down because he couldn’t look after him properly. “He found it dficult to get about and we don’t have anyone  who can help, so the only option left was for me to give up work. “It wasn’t an easy decision to make and we went from having a regular income to relying on Jobseekers Allowance of pound every two weeks.  “It was a struggle to pay bills, buy food and heat our home, but at least we had some money coming in. I received three payments until I was sent a letter from the DWP saying my benefits were being stopped because I had voluntarily made myself redundant. “I’d already explained the circumstances surrounding my decision to stop working and was told that I could claim benefits – but in a matter of weeks they changed their minds.” The couple were advised to go to their local Jobcentre and apply for Universal Credit but were then told they did not qualy for support. Victoria claims she was also told she wouldn’t be able to receive any JSA payment until February , . Gerald, who worked with Glasgow City Council before his stroke, said: “We begged but the staff showed no interest and basically left us penniless. “They knew Victoria was pregnant and we had a little boy to feed. “I showed them my medical reports but nothing mattered and they refused to help. “We don’t qualy for Universal Credit and I lost my own claim when Victoria moved in with me. We were devastated and very stressed by what we’d been put through.” After suffering the miscarriage, Victoria was rushed by ambulance to the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Glasgow. Related video: A single mum on Universal Credit can’t afford school unorms for kids  Fighting back tears, she said: “I was very stressed and angry at what we’d been put through at the job centre. “The only ray of light was the fact that we were having a little baby and it was something we were all looking forward to. “We always wanted Patrick to have a brother or a sister and it just felt like a blessing. “The pregnancy was going really well and I was due to have our first scan the following week. “When I went into the shower, I felt that something was wrong. “My waters broke and I could feel I was losing the baby. It broke my heart and I just couldn’t believe what was happening. “It was too early to knowour baby was a boy or a girl and I stood with this tiny body in my hands. I didn’t know what to do with it.” “I believe the stress the DWP put me through caused me to lose our baby. “The doctors told me that stress could have been a factor in my miscarriage.  “A post-mortem is taking place and we will know more about what happened in four weeks.” The family are now relying on handouts from a food bank to survive and face an anxious wait to seethe qualy for a hardship payment. Victoria added: “I feel abandoned and badly let down by the DWP. We’ve been left penniless. “We are trying to come to terms with losing our baby and I’m still worrying about how we will make ends meet. “The DWP need to think about the stress they put people under before they cut off vital support.” A DWP spokeswoman said: “We have invited Ms Bagnall to the Jobcentre to discuss the support available. Decisions for JSA are made following consideration of all the information provided by the claimant. “Sanctions are only used in a small percentage of cases, when people fail to meet agreed commitments infor benefits. “People can apply for a hardship payment, which does not have to be repaid back. “Anyone who disagrees with a decision has the right to appeal.” What is Jobseekers Allowance  People can apply for Jobseekers Allowanceto help them as they look for work. First, they must check to seethey are eligible and,they are, make a claim and go to an interview at a local Jobcentre Plus office. Once they receive payments they must keep to their agreement to look for work. Otherwise, the payments will be stopped. There is a maximum amount a person can receive, and how much they are entitled to depends on things such as their age, income and savings. title: meghan markle cradles blooming baby

In the clearest image of her bump yet, The Duchess gently placed her hands on her stomach while stood alongside Harry at their evening event. Meghan dazzled in diamonds to go with the blue, cape dress by label SAFiYAA at a black tie reception on the first night of in Fiji. Her outfit, worn with her hair down, was by German-born London-based designer Daniela Karmuts. Guests, including diplomats, local business leaders and the cream of Fijian society, gathered for the champagne reception ahead of the state dinner at the Grand Pacic Hotel where the royal couple are staying during the visit.  The hotel is a royal favourite, with The Queen staying there five times, in , , ,  and . Prince Charles has checked in three times, in ,  and  and Prince Andrew stayed in . Princess Ann was a guest in . The hotels website states: Once established as the standard of luxury that was fit for royalty now more than  years later, the Grand Pacic Hotel remains true to the ideals of delivering the best of old world charms, South Pacic hospitality and contemporary service.  Earlier today, the royal couple were welcomed to Fiji with a traditional ceremony where they were presented with a roast pig, a whale’s tooth and a taste of the traditional local brew, kava. The ceremony, under cloudy skies in Suva’s Albert Park, mirrored one attended by the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh in . But the weather didn’t stop thousands of people packing the streets leading to Albert Park to greet them. The Duchess of Sussex waved to the crowd from the motorcade, as the couple arrived to cheers for the Veirqaraqarvi Vakavanua where they were greeted by chiefs in a tradition known as the tama. The crowd, slightly damp from the rain shower or “a bit of blessing” as the master of ceremonies put it, cheered and waved Union Jacks and Fijian flags as the couple arrived.  Hundreds maintained reverential silence which is the custom - with only the occasional burst of children chatting or a nearby clock chiming - heard over the rhythmic drums and chanting of the ceremony. Harry and Meghan sat on a stage as he was given the whale’s tooth, a sign of wealth, in the vakasobu, before he were given kava, a drink made from a mashed plant root in the yaqona vakaturaga. Harry, his medals catching the floodlights, looked on as the kava was made with the root wrung out and a bowl passed to the Duke on the stage. The area is known for its strong links to the armed forces and Harry was proudly displaying three medals on his suit, an Afghanistan operational service medal and the Queen Elizabeth II Golden and Diamond Jubilee medals. The Duke and Duchess were also pictured waving from the balcony of the Grand Pacic Hotel to adoring crowds below. At this evenings state banquet, Harry gave a speech where he spoke about the nostalgic visit to the hotel where the Queen and Prince Phillip have stayed a number of times. Prince Harrys speech in full Your Excellency President Konrote and First Lady Madam Sarote, Honourable Prime Minister, representatives from all Opposition Parties, Ladies and Gentlemen, Bula Vinaka. It is a great pleasure for Meghan and me to be your guests here tonight on our first visit to Fiji. We were overwhelmed by the warm Fijian welcome we received from the people of these beautul islands this afternoon in Albert Park, and all the way from the airport! It really is a privilege to be here. As you know, Fiji has a long tradition of welcoming Royal visitors over the years and our two countries have enjoyed a close relationship and friendship. We share Commonwealth values and common goals – a love of rugby and a sense of humour! Our ties run deep. Your soldiers fought with the British Armed Forces during the First and Second World Wars and continue to serve alongside our soldiers to this day, with more than , Fijians currently serving. I must emphasise my respect, admiration and camaraderie with the Fijian soldiers that I served with in Afghanistan. We trained together, we fought together, and most importantly we laughed together.  This visit is particularly nostalgic for us as a young married couple – my grandparents stayed in this very hotel, the Grand Pacic, a number of times over the years. But this visit is also an opportunity to learn more about the future of Fiji, your economic growth, sustainable tourism development and social enterprises. We are really looking forward to meeting the students at the University of the South Pacic and the young leaders from all walks of le. The health and sustainability of this planet depends on the younger generation, and they are full of optimism so let’s listen to them. I’m very glad that the British Government is increasing its support for Fiji and the region, and we are proud of the long-standing collaboration between the UK and Fiji on climate change and in fact, the UK just hosted its own Talanoa on climate change across Great Britain earlier this month.  We look to Fiji to provide leadership on environmental issues which affect all of us, and that have been affecting you as an island nation for many, many years. Fiji is a proud and vibrant culture whose people are so gentle but proud, honourable and resourceful. Your country has demonstrated its fortitude and resilience by rebuilding your communities following the devastating Cyclone Winston two years ago. You continue to smile, you continue to have hope, and you continue to share what you have with others. All over the world Fiji is renowned for its incredible natural beauty and hospitality. We, as a couple, feel very lucky to be spending part of our tour as your guests. Your Excellency, through you, I would also like to wish the people of Fiji the very best for a successful election in November. Vinaka Vakalevu.

title: identical twins who were born
story: NewsIdentical twins who were born girls are now brothers after they both came out as transgenderJack and Jace Grafe, , underwent chest surgery side-by-side in Georgia, US, and say being male feels naturalShareCommentsByShanti Das:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsJace, left, and Jack, right, say it now feels natural to be brothers after they transitioned together "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo identical twins who were born girls have now become brothers. Transgender siblings Jack and Jace Grafe, , used to cry themselves to sleep and prayed to wake up as boys when they were children. They started le as Jaclyn and Jenner in June , and grew up in a conservative Christian home. Jack and Jace grew up in Baltimore, Maryland, before moving to Monroe, Georgia. They came out at the age of  and are now transitioning as a duo in a rare case. The twins, who have the same DNA, have grown facial hair since they began taking testosterone in April  and underwent chest surgery in August.  Now the criminal justice graduates, who both work in law enforcement, have shared their extraordinary story in a bid to inspire others. Jack, a deputy sherfs officer, said: As a kid I would cry and pray to God that I would wake up in a male body, not even understanding that being transgender was a thing. Now, I am the happiest with myself that I have been in my entire le. That uncomfortable feeling we had before has completely gone. When we came out, it was to our whole family - mum, dad and our older sister.  Our parents had never seen anything like it. They have never experienced gay or transgender people and my dad is a pastor. We live in Georgia. At work I have had my fair share of people calling me a s*** - she, he, it. Usually they just dont understand. People still refer to us as female. Whenever I hear she or her it is like a kick in the stomach. It hurts but I get it. At a young age, I was skeptical of it myself. For some people, it is a hard pill to swallow. There are times when I wish I was just born - and I dont mean this in a negative way -but normal, and that I was biologically male.  People say, You will never be able to change your chromosomes, you can only change the outside. There are still times when I come home and break down. Jace, who is also a deputy officer and just started in the police academy, added: Honestly, the twin thing has helped. If I was to go back to when I was  or  I would never think in a million years that I would have got to this point. It was a fantasy and I always wished it was going to happy but I wasnt brave enough. I didnt have the guts. Being a twin means I dont feel alone. Somebody  is experiencing the exact same things as I am going through and that made me stronger.  Growing up, the Grafe girls wore boyish clothes, assumed the role of dad or brother when playing house and, as teenagers, had crushes on female classmates. But they also attended a strict religious school and say they ran the risk of being thrown outthey also revealed their feelings so didn’t tell anyone - not even each other. Then, at the age of , the twins began attending cosplay conventions where they dressed up as male characters - something they both say “felt natural”. When they finished high school they hacked off their hair and they later came out to one another, firstly as gay aged  and two years later as transgender.  Five years on Jace, of Athens, Georgia, is dating Emory College student Jess Smith, , and Jack is engaged to bakery manager Maygon Arrington, , whom he lives with in nearby Monroe, Georgia. Jack said: It was even hard to tell each other that we liked girls, but when I told Jace and askedhe would have a dferent opinion of me he was like, ‘No, I feel the same way.’ “When he said ‘me too’ I felt relieved and not alone any more. It was scary. I was honestly terried.” Jace added: “I felt the same way about the whole thing. We talked to each other about everything but this was the one subject we were awkward about. We were raised in a really religious household and didnt want to tell each other how we were feeling because we were scared the other would judge us.  “I was scared because I held my twins opinion higher than anybody  sohe didnt accept me I would be devastated. “At one point I even tried to date a guy to seethe feelings would go away but they didn’t.“I found out Jack was transgender through a Facebook post on his profile, which was specically for our cosplay friends and had no family.“I was like, ‘If you feel like this why didn’t you tell me ’ He said it was awkward, that it was much more than saying, ‘Oh, I like girls.’ “I said, ‘Well,you talked to me you would have known that that is how I feel as well.’ “After that we decided to refer to ourselves as brothers and asked our cosplay friends to refer to us as male.” Despite not coming out until adulthood and keeping their gender identity secret from each other, both twins felt the same way - that they were male, not female. Recent studies suggest identical twins are more likely to simultaneously experience gender dysphoria than non-identical twins. Of  monozygotic or identical twins,  per cent were concordant for gender identity disorder, according to a literature review published in the Journal of Sexual Medicine. None of the  dizygotic - non-identical - twins were concordant, suggesting a possible genetic or biological link with being transgender. As well as identying as men at work and home, the Grafe twins have been legally recognized as male by the state as of September . They were permitted to change the gender marker on their driving licenses after undergoing chest surgery side by side on August  at Georgia Plastic Surgery. Dr Sheldon Lincenberg removed their breast tissue and contoured their chests to make the area appear more masculine.  Their identity is set inside themselves, Dr. Lincenberg told Fox . Theyre not trying to change that. They just want the world to see them as they are. Jack added: It was like a weight lted off my shoulders. story: NewsNASA discovers incredible mile long and perfectly rectangular iceberg floating in the AntarcticThe space agency photoed the unusual sight from a flight documenting icebergs in the ArcticShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  OCT NewsThe astonishing iceberg appears to have perfectly straight edges "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn astonishing mile-long block of floating ice has been discovered floating in Antarctica with perfectly straight edges. Amazingly the iceberg was formed completely naturally.It was spotted by NASA staff, who shared the picture on Twitter . The space agency wrote: From yesterdaysIceBridge flight: A tabular iceberg can be seen on the right, floating among sea ice just off of the Larsen C ice shelf.The icebergs sharp angles and flat surface indicate that it probably recently calved from the ice shelf.  The IceBridge flight is a survey of the planets polar ice, and is providing a D of the ice in the Arctic and Antarctic. NASA scientist Kelly Brunt told LiveScience: We get two types of icebergs: We get the type that everyone can envision in their head that sank the Titanic, and they look like prisms or triangles at the surface and you know they have a crazy subsurface. And then you have what are called tabular icebergs.  These are blocks of ice which split from ice shelves in the same way a fingernail cracks offit grows too long. But she admitted this particular iceberg was a bit unusual. It is thought to have broken from the Larsen C ice shelf, the largest one in Antarctica. story: Dundee defender Andy Boyle admits he was shocked by Neil McCann’s departure as Dundee boss but says they must move on under new man Jim McIntyre.Boyle was one of the last signings McCann made for the Dark Blues at the end of the summer transfer window and he has made a good impact, so far, scoring in the - win at Hamilton – Dundee’s only league win of the season.And the Irish centre-back bubbly,” the -year-old said.“We had a quick chat with what the manager expects of us and what way he wants us to play.“We’ve had some good training sessions, full of energy and enjoyable.“As professional footballers we have to be ready for all kinds of situations and, either way, we knew we were going to be in on Wednesday morning and had games to prepare for.“From Tuesday when Neil “Lads will probably speak to Kenny and ask him about what they’ll face in their dferent positions.“Since I’ve been here Kenny’s been brilliant, he knows the game very well and has a huge pedigree in the game so he’s a big help.“Livingston have the articial pitch and that will be dficult compared to what we’re used to but we showed against Hamilton that we can play on that.“We know it’ll be a test for us because, obviously, they have gone so well at the start of the season.“It’s a game we believe we can get a positive result from.”And the Dee will be hoping they can pick up some points as it regular matches because of the international break, Boyle feels they’ll be ready for the challenge of playing two games in four days.Boyle said: “As players you want to play as many games as Where this happens, we will seek to redeploy our colleagues and communicate to our customers the alternatives available to them."A spokesman for the Inverness Business Improvement Districtsaid the move obviously reflected a change in the industry.The BrightHouse closure announcement comes a year after the firm was ordered to repay pound. million to nearly , customers by the Financial Conduct Authority.It found BrightHouse had not been a "responsible lender".And BrightHouse last year announced that it was set to close a number of its stores as it struggled to cope with increased regulatory scrutiny of its business practices.This prompted a response from the Centre for Responsible Credit, which said it would "shed no tears"BrightHouse collapsed.BrightHouse did not wish to comment.
